body.p:
Jonhanns case
Peny,
Louisville Ky 25th Jany 1861 --
To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky --

Your petitioner would most respectfully state That he was tried in the Circuit Court ^this Term^ for Rescuing a person named John Kegan from the custody of two supernumary Watchmen sometime last July -- & found guilty & sentenced to the Penitentiary house for the Term of One Year -- all which is most unjust -- The day on which this took place a Prize fight was to come off in the state of Indiana about 12 miles above this city & two small Steam Boats were chartered to carry the spectators, the fight from some cause did not come off, but there were several Pistol shots & two or more sleightly wounded, the Boat returned to the city with the passengers & after landing a fight was commenced with fists between two men who had some difficulty before at the place appointed for the fight whilst thus engaged Kegan approached the combatants & fired his pistol at one of the them by name of Welsh Killing him instantly
& then fled down the wharf, pursued by one of the afsd supernumeray policemen or rather extra Deputy Marshals, (acting as policemen, in evasion of the police Bill) as it ^is^ more properly called -- nearly a square distant, entering a house & passing to another door out of which he was escaping, at that point he was caught by the officer, when he was caught hold of by the petitioner, for only an instant, another officer came up at the time to aid in the arrest the petitioner approached him, but upon being informed that he was an officer immediately withdrew saying if he was an officer he would not molest him The first Officer ordered the second officer to shoot the petitioner & he snapped his Revolver pistol at him, afterwards the first officer turned upon the petitioner with a drawn Bowie Knife & gave him three severe and almost fatal stabs in the side next the heart, but in consequence of this delay Kegan escaped out of the door fled through the crowd entered a house near by & has not yet been arrested -- The petitioner isSays he is a stranger here did not ^Know^ Kegan or the officers as they had no badge & supposed they were following a man for the purpose
of beating him or seriously injuring him which he endeavored to prevent, the man fleeing was a very small man & the person after him was quite a large man he did not announce himself a policeman or any indication of acting under authority of law, & which I state in truth & in fact I did not believe they or either of them were officers, nor did I know that any body had been shot or Killed -- at that time, my wounds were painful & how I escaped being Killed by the pistol or Knife was miraculous indeed -- This last October I was tried by a Jury I had no wtnesses the same officers testified at both trials, their statements were not exactly alike, the Jury composed of some of the most respectable & intelligent gentlemen in the city or state such as Mr William Pope & others like him were for acquitting they stood six & Six viz equally divided I was afterward told that there were three old policemen on the Jury who prevented a verdict of acquittal then, the influence of men intheir situation can not be successfully restated here

I have ^been^ in jail almost ever since July 1860 -- I am a stranger here am not guilty of intentional violation of Laws am the only child of a widowed mother living in New Orleans have no relatives in this state -- & I now pray yr Excellency to Pardon me & I will strive ever to deserve so great a boon

ToThe foregoing petition I drew and am sure the statement is entirely true as to the evidence adduced & proceedings of the two trials, I am also concerned this is an extremely hard case & no other would have been convicted under similar circumstances I fully concur in the petitioners prayer for pardon and am authorized to sign the name of Mr Hodges assistant counsel to this but will not he was about to leave for New Castle & had no pen to sign his name with great respect I am sir yr obliged humble servt
